summary: influenza H17 and H18 viruses originated from bats, the waterfowl are known as a primordial reservoir for all subtypes of IAV. different subtypes of H5Nx HPAI viruses pose a substantial threat to global health with high mortality rate and huge economic burden. the clade 2.3.2.1 of H5N1 HPAI virus was first identified in 2004. since then other subclades, including 2.3.2.1a, 2.3.2.1b, and 2.3.2.1c, have evolved. rapid and highly accurate methods are necessary for the detection and control of the IAV outbreaks. Reference Viruses and Field Samples Collection A total of 15 reference influenza virus samples were obtained from the Korea Research Institute of Bioscience and Biotechnology (KRIBB) and National Vietnam University of Agriculture. all the reference influenza viruses were propagated in the allantoic fluid of 9–11 days old embryonated specific pathogen-free chicken eggs. the following primers and probes were used: HA forward primer, CCAGCCAATGACCTYTGT; HA reverse primer, GRTAAGCCAYACCACATTTC; Pan H5-HPAI probe, Texas red-TGARGAAYTGAAACACCTATTGAGCAG-BHQ2. all amplicons obtained using one set of HA primers were 201 base pairs in length. one-step multiplex RT-qPCR analysis was performed using the RNeasy Mini Kit (Hilden, Germany) the one-step multiplex RT-qPCR reaction mixture contained 0.8 L of enzyme mixture, 4 L of 5 reaction buffer, 0.8 L of deoxynucleoside triphosphate (10 pmol) from a Qiagen kit. equine influenza virus (H3N8 subtype), 1 canine influenza virus (H3N2), 1 swine influenza virus (H3N2), avian infectious bronchitis virus, Newcastle disease virus, human Coronavirus-229E, and human Parainfluenza were assessed using one-step multiplex RT-qPCR described in this study. all H5 HPAI experiments were conducted in a biosafety level 3 containment facility in KRIBB and biosafety level 2 plus facilities. field samples from 12 farms in Vietnam were taken from domestic chickens with signs of respiratory illness in 2016 to 2018. one-step multiplex RT-qPCR assays were performed using a serial 10-fold dilution (5 108 to 5 100 copies of plasmid DNA/L) each plasmid was cloned using the Mighty TA cloning kit. the one-step multiplex RT-qPCR reaction mixture contained 0.8 L of enzyme mixture. the PCR thermocycling procedure was performed at 50 °C for 30 min. the next step was performed at 94 °C for 20 s, 56 °C for 20 s, and 72 °C for 30 s for 40 cycles. fluorescence data were acquired during the annealing step to distinguish positive and negative results. specific amplicons were purified from 1.5% agarose gels using a QIAquick Gel Extraction Kit (Hilden, Germany) and sequenced using an ABI PRISM 3730 DNA Sequencer. all H5 HPAI-positive field viruses were classified as the H5 HPAI clade using Highly Pathogenic H5N1 Clade classification tool. the detection limit under both conditions was 5 101 copies per microliter. the cut-off for the cycle threshold of RT-qPCR was set to 35. each concentration had triple replicates and the mean and SD were conducted using GraphPad Prism software. strains of different subtypes or clades of influenza A virus, as well as other avian or human origin viruses, infectious bronchitis virus, Newcastle disease virus, coronavirus-229E strain and parainfluenza virus 1 were tested. Clade 2.3.2.1c Clade 2.3.4.4 Clade A/California/04/2009 Human GQ280797 H1N1 ND ND ND A/wild bird/Korea/SK14/2014 Avian KX066871 H1N1 ND ND ND ND LPAI A/swine/Korea/CAN04/2005 Swine EU798790 H3N2 ND ND ND A/canine/K 68 samples were confirmed influenza positive by RT-qPCR. each clade was successfully analyzed using our one-step multiplex RT-qPCR assay. each clade was successfully classified using the Influenza Research Database. the pan-H5 HPAI-specific and two clade-specific multiplex RT-qPCR assays were well-matched. the results show that our one-step multiplex RT-qPCR assay could be a promising technique for specific discrimination of multiple H5 HPAI viruses. 63 23.19 23.56 ND ND 2.3.2.1c Feces sample #10 + 22.29 22.15 22.64 23.26 ND ND 2.3.2.1c Feces sample #11 + 20.33 19.68 20.4 21.1 ND ND 2.3.2.1c Feces sample #12 + 20.13 21 ND ND 20.7 21.97 2.3.4.4 Feces sample #13 + 19.48 22.59 ND 22.33 21.24 2.3. LPAI Feces sample #28 + ND ND ND ND ND LPAI Feces sample #29 + ND ND ND ND ND LPAI Feces sample #31 + ND ND ND ND ND LPAI Feces sample #32 + ND ND ND ND ND ND LPAI Feces sample #33 + ND ND ND ND ND ND LPAI Feces sample #34 + ND ND ND 2.3.2.1c Feces sample #47 + 23.36 23.21 23.86 23.76 ND ND 2.3.2.1c Feces sample #48 + 18.88 18.94 ND ND 19.88 20.05 2.3.4.4 Feces sample #49 + 23.6 24.3 23.42 24.52 ND ND 2.3.2.1c Feces sample #50 + 23.9 24.14 24.16 24.6 ND ND 2.3.2.1c Feces sample #51 + 22 ND 19.16 19.3 2.3.4.4 Feces sample #65 + ND ND ND ND ND LPAI Feces sample #66 + 23.79 23.94 24.28 24.4 ND ND 2.3.2.1a Feces sample #67 + 23.78 23.78 23.83 24.25 ND ND 2.3.2.1a Feces sample #68 + 24.25 24.37 24.47 24.66 ND 2.3.2.1c ND: not detected; primers and probes for pan-H5 HPAI and two clades, 2.3.4.4 or 2.3.2.1, were designed. each plasmid was serially diluted (5 108 to 5 100 copies per microliter) the detection limit under both qPCR conditions was 5 101 copies per microliter. singleplex (A,C,E) and multiplex (B,D,F) realtime-qPCR assays were performed using standard plasmids corresponding to clades 2.3.4.4 and 2.3.2.1. each concentration had triple replicates. all avian or human origin viruses, infectious bronchitis virus, Newcastle disease virus, coronavirus-229E strain, and parainfluenza virus 1 were successfully detected. the other influenza A virus subtypes and viruses of other origin were not amplified by our multiplex RT-qPCR. ND Clade 2.2 A/duck/Vietnam/NCVD-1648/2012 Avian KY171342 H5N1 20.58 21.6 ND Clade 2.3.2.1c A/aquatic bird/Korea/CN2/2009 Avian KY584075 H5N2 ND ND ND LPAI A/Environment/Korea/W541/2016 Avian KY272997 H5N6 22.13 ND 21. a total of 4350 fecal samples were confirmed influenza positive by RT-qPCR. 68 samples were confirmed influenza positive by M-gene-specific RT-qPCR. each clade was successfully classified using the Influenza Research Database. ND ND 2.3.2.1c Feces sample #54 + 18.97 18.53 ND ND 18.3 18.94 2.3.4.4 Feces sample #55 + 23.3 23.22 23.17 22.93 ND ND 2.3.2.1c Feces sample #56 + 22.42 22.79 22.94 23 ND ND 2.3.2.1c Feces sample #57 + 22.8 22.92 22.43 22.36 ND ND 2.3.2.1c Feces sample #58 each concentration had triple replicates. the validity of this assay was confirmed using M-gene positive field samples, H5Nx HPAI viruses for positive control and Newcastle Disease virus for negative control. 2.3.4.4 clade of H5 HPAI virus has spread to china and neighboring countries, such as south Korea [24], Vietnam [25], and Laos [26] between 2013 and 2016. virus isolation is the gold standard for influenza virus diagnosis, but is time-consuming, expensive, and not suitable for discrimination of multiple HPAI viruses. one-step multiplex RT-qPCR assay was successfully employed to amplify viruses and IAV-positive field samples. the limit of detection of pan-H5 HPAI and clades was the same when our new single primer set and each probe combination was used.
